content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Optibase OBAS, +0.00% said it's signed a non-binding term sheet to sell its digital video and streaming business to Scopus Video Networks SCOP, -0.89% for 2.6 million Scopus shares. Scopus may issue to Optibase up to additional 900,000 ordinary shares depending on sales goals being met.
title: Scopus reaches tentative deal to buy Optibase for stock

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of the following companies were among those making notable moves in the U.S. stock market Wednesday. Advancers Akeena Solar Inc. AKNS shares surged 44%. The small-cap firm said it inked a licensing deal with Suntech Power Holdings to distribute its Andalay solar panel technology in Europe, Japan and Australia. Suntech targets sales of over 10 megawatts of the Andalay solar panels to the licensed regions in 2008. Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -3.86% shares gained 3.9%. It got upgraded to a buy rating from hold by Citigroup Wednesday morning. In a note to clients, analyst Mark Mahaney said "general consolidation" in the stock's price since late July has created a buying opportunity. See full story. Broadcom BRCM shares were higher. It won an order from a federal judge prohibiting Qualcomm QCOM, -1.64% from using certain Broadcom technology. Qualcomm said it expects an "immediate, short-term impact" on the company from the order that it stop marketing certain of its products. It didn't specify the impact. It did say it's developing workarounds for the patents in question. See full story. Cameron International Corp. CAM, -1.67% shares gained 3.7%. It received a $190 million contract to provide subsea equipment and services to the Venezuelan national oil company Petroleos De Venezuela S.A. Under the terms of the agreement, which consists of three packages, Cameron will provide 10 subsea Christmas trees, wellheads, associated production control systems, in-field jumpers and flowline connection systems, and other services for PDVSA's Dragon and Patao natural gas development projects. Chesapeake Energy CHK, -3.48% shares rose. It on Wednesday said it sold $1.1 billion in natural gas production rights to affiliates of UBS AG UBS, +0.03% and DB Energy Trading LLC, a subsidiary of Deutsche Bank AG. DB, -0.79% American depositary receipts of LDK Solar Co., LDK the Xinyu City, China, producer of multicrystalline solar wafers, the raw material for solar cells, gained 5%. It estimated 2008 revenue at $960 million to $1 billion and its gross-profit margin at 26% to 31% of revenue. The company also estimated its 2009 gross margin at 42% to 50%. Nautilus Inc. NLS, -0.56% shares were higher. Shareholder votes confirmed that all four Sherborne Investors LP nominees were elected to Nautilus's board, the companies said. The final voting results also showed that all of Sherborne Investors' other proposals were passed. Scopus Video Networks Ltd. SCOP, -0.89% shares rose. Optibase Ltd., OBAS, +0.00% the Herzliya, Israel, provider of services to telecommunications operators, broadcasters and content creators, said on Tuesday that it agreed to lift its stake to 37% from 27% in the Rosh ha'Ayin, Israel, provider of digital-video-networking equipment. Optibase said it agreed to buy the additional stake from Scopus holders, paying $8.6 million for 1.38 million shares. That's an indicated $6.23 apiece, reflecting a premium of 15% over Scopus Video's closing price on Monday of $5.44. Sunoco Inc. SUN, -0.20% shares rose. Soleil Securities analyst Jacques H. Rousseau cut his earnings estimate on the oil firm, but reiterated his buy rating. Rousseau said he expects fourth-quarter earnings of 54 cents a share, down from 79 cents a share. Decliners Advanced Micro Devices AMD, -1.99% shares fell 4.8%. It was downgraded to sell from neutral at Banc of America Securities, which said it is still premature to bottom-fish the stock despite a 62% drop in 2007. Shares of Alaska Air Group Inc. ALK, -2.52% slipped 5.4%. Shareholders said they want more influence over executive compensation, requesting the company allow shareholders to form an advisory group. AMR Corp.'s AMR, -1.94% shares lost 5.2%. Its growth could lag behind that of its peers and be weighed down by higher fuel costs, Goldman Sachs said Wednesday in a note to investors, and slashed its fourth-quarter earnings estimate for the airline operator. The investment firm said it now expects AMR to post a quarterly loss of 71 cents a share compared to its prior outlook of a 14 cents-a-share loss. Boeing Co. BA, -0.20% shares were lower. Jeju Air ordered five 737-800s for $370 million, the South Korea carrier's first Boeing planes to enter its fleet. Jeju Air flies between the resort island of Jeju and South Korea's mainland. Horizon Bancorp HBNC, +0.27% shares fell 5.9%. It increased its provision for loan-and lease-loss expense by $1.4 million in December, citing credit quality deterioration in its wholesale-mortgage and indirect auto-loan portfolios. The commercial-bank-holding company expects its fourth-quarter provision expense to total $1.8 million, compared to the third-quarter provision of $550,000. Horizon still sees 2007 full-year earnings exceeding those of 2006. International Business Machines Corp. IBM, -0.79% shares lost 3.1%. It said it acquired XIV, a Tel Aviv storage-technology company. Terms weren't disclosed, but the Israeli daily Globes reported earlier this week that the price under discussion had been $300 million to $350 million. Merrill Lynch & Co. MER, -2.35% shares were lower. It was in talks this weekend with Chinese and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds to raise more capital in a bid to stave off liquidity concerns following massive credit losses, the U.K. Observer reported. See full story. CNBC also reported that the brokerage firm may cut 1,600 jobs soon and unveil write-downs of as much as $10 billion. National City Corp. NCC, -0.16% shares dropped 5.3%. It said Wednesday that its cutting its quarterly dividend 49%, laying off 900 mortgage staffers and making plans to raise new money to bolster capital ratios. The firm declared a dividend of 21 cents a share, payable Feb. 1 with a record date of Jan. 14. The firm previously paid a dividend of 41 cents a share. See full story. Shares of PHH Corp., PHH, +0.29% the Mount Laurel, N.J., provider of residential-mortgage and vehicle-fleet-management services, fell 3.1%. It said it ended its plan to be acquired by General Electric Co.'s GE, -1.11% GE Capital financing unit. The deal, reached in mid-March, had been valued at $31.50 a share, or $1.69 billion. As a condition of the deal, an affiliate of the New York investment firm Blackstone Group BX, -1.71% was to acquire PHH's mortgage business from GE Capital. See full story. Quest Software Inc. QSFT shares lost 3.8%. It has filed its reports for the quarters ended March 31, June 30 and Sept. 30, 2007, with the Securities and Exchange Commission and is now current with all its SEC reporting obligations. Retalix Ltd. RTLX shares tumbled 15%. Chief Operating Officer Avinoam Bloch is leaving the Ra'anana, Israel, producer of management systems for supermarkets, a company spokesman said. The spokesman confirmed a report in the Israeli business daily Globes that Bloch was leaving. Globes reported that sources told the paper that the executive was leaving because of professional differences with President and Chief Executive Barry Shaked. Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -1.43% shares lost 5.7%. Bear Stearns on Wednesday lowered its rating for Starbucks Corp. to peer perform from outperfrom as people trim their spending habits as the broader economy cools off. Also impacting the coffee-making chain are higher labor and dairy costs, the investment firm said in a note to investors. Textron Inc. TXT, -0.58% shares dropped 6.3%. It was downgraded Wednesday to hold from buy at Citi, which citied the stock's more than 50% climb in 2007. "We still see a potential upside in our estimates, but the 'Street' has now caught up and possible additional earnings upside appears to be largely priced in," Citi said in a note to investors. In 2007, Textron shares rose 52% to $71.69 from $47.43. The Providence, R.I.-based Textron builds aircraft through its Cessna and Bell units, and has been benefiting from high global demand for its private business jets and aircraft. VeriFone Holdings Inc. PAY, -1.69% shares slumped 15%. It said it probably will not be able to submit its annual report before March despite asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to extend the deadline to Jan. 14. VeriFone is restating its financial reports for the first three quarters of its year ended Oct. 31, 2007. It said it's uncertain how long the restatement will take. YRC Worldwide Inc. YRCW, -1.47% shares fell 9.7%. It expects to incur non-cash impairment charges during the fourth quarter of 2007 of $650 million to $750 million, after taxes. The charges are related to prior acquisitions. The Overland Park, Kan., transportation service provider doesn't expect the impairment charges to have any impact on the company's cash flow or availability of financing under existing debt facilities. content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Wednesday's session are Merrill Lynch, Motorola, PHH, and Vonage. U.S. markets will be closed Tuesday in observance of the New Year holiday Watch list South Korea-based Jeju Air ordered five 737-800s for $370 million, Boeing Co. BA, -0.23% said. The 737s will be the first Boeing airplanes to enter the Jeju Air fleet. Jeju Air provides domestic flights between the resort island of Jeju and South Korea's mainland. Commerce Bancorp Inc. CBH, +0.00% completed the sale of its insurance brokerage business, Commerce Insurance Services, to a group led by Commerce Insurance Services' Chairman George E. Norcross and President Michael Tiagwad, Commerce Bancorp said. The sale includes the commercial property and casualty, employee benefits, and various specialty insurance lines of Commerce Insurance Services. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Horizon Bancorp HBNC, +0.10% increased its provision for loan and lease losses expense by $1.4 million in December, citing credit quality deterioration in its wholesale mortgage and indirect auto loan portfolios. The commercial bank-holding company expects its fourth-quarter provision expense to total $1.77 million, compared to the third-quarter provision of $550,000. However, Horizon still sees 2007 full-year earnings exceeding those of 2006. Merrill Lynch & Co. MER, -2.35% was in talks this weekend with Chinese and Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds to raise more capital in a bid to stave off liquidity concerns following massive credit losses, the British newspaper the Observer reported. Chief Executive John Thain is trying to secure another infusion of foreign capital through selling stock or assets to shore up Merrill's balance sheet, the Observer reported, citing anonymous sources. See full story Motorola Inc. MSI, -0.91% and Metrologic Instruments Inc. have reached an agreement that settles all outstanding patent infringement disputes between the companies and their subsidiaries, Motorola said. As a part of the agreement, the companies have entered into a patent cross-license for a limited term in the field of barcode scanning and mobile computing. Terms of the settlement are confidential. Nasdaq Stock Market Inc. NDAQ, -0.74% has received clearance from The Committee on Foreign Investment for Borse Dubai's investment in Nasdaq, the New York-based exchange said Monday. The approval paves the way for Nasdaq to proceed with its purchase of Stockholm-based OMX AB and allows Borse Dubai to transfer its OMX shares to Nasdaq once its stake in OMX reaches at least 67%, Nasdaq said. Nasdaq had originally announced the approval on Friday but withdrew the announcement, noting that it was distributed in error. Nautilus Inc. NLS, -0.37% and Sherborne Investors LP said shareholder votes confirmed that all four Sherborne Investors nominees were elected to Nautilus' board. The final voting results, which were certified by IVS Associates, also showed that all of Sherborne Investors' other proposals were passed. PHH Corp., PHH, +0.38% the Mount Laurel, N.J., provider of residential-mortgage and vehicle-fleet-management services, said it ended its plan to be acquired by General Electric Co.'s GE, -1.37% GE Capital financing unit. The deal, reached in mid-March, had been valued at $31.50 a share, or $1.69 billion. As a condition of the deal, an affiliate of the New York investment firm Blackstone Group BX, -1.61% was to acquire PHH's mortgage business from GE Capital. PHH said it had been notified that the Blackstone entity was unable to secure financing for this part of the deal. Thus, PHH said it is seeking a $50 million merger-termination fee from the Blackstone unit. PHH's board will review whether to continue the company's plan to review its strategic alternatives, Chairman A.B. Krongard said in a statement on Tuesday. Quest Software Inc. QSFT has filed its quarterly reports for the periods ended March 31, June 30 and Sept. 30, 2007 with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. As a result, the company is now current with all its SEC periodic reporting obligations. Optibase Ltd., OBAS, +0.00% the Herzliya, Israel, provider of services to telecommunications operators, broadcasters and content creators, said on Tuesday that it agreed to lift its stake in Scopus Video Networks Ltd. SCOP, -0.89% to 37% from 27%. Scopus is the Rosh ha'Ayin, Israel, provider of digital-video-networking equipment. Optibase said it agreed to buy the additional share from Scopus holders, paying $8.6 million for 1.38 million shares. That's an indicated $6.23 apiece, reflecting a premium of 15% over Scopus Video's closing price on Monday of $5.44. A statement from Optibase didn't say why it boosted the holding in Scopus, nor did it identify the selling shareholders. VeriFone Holdings Inc. PAY, -1.76% said it probably will not be able to submit its annual report before March despite requesting an extension of the deadline to Jan. 14 with the Securities and Exchange Commission. VeriFone is in the process of restating financial statements for the first three quarters of its fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 2007. It also noted that it is not certain how much time will be required for it to complete the restatement process. Vonage Holdings Corp. VG, -1.03% has agreed in principle with Nortel Networks Corp. NT to end pending litigation. According to a release from Vonage, the contemplated settlement involves a limited cross-license to three Nortel and three Vonage patents and does not call for monetary payments. Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, a subsidiary of IntercontinentalExchange ICE, -1.46% will be known as ICE Futures Canada, effective Jan. 1, IntercontinentalExchange said Monday. The name change is in line with ICE's other futures subsidiaries, ICE Futures U.S. and ICE Futures Europe, the exchange operator said. content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Optibase obas said all the conditions have been met for it to proceed with its tender offer for 5% of Scopus Video Networks scop for $5.75 a share in cash. As of Aug. 31, 4.89 million shares were tendered. Scopus closed Thursday at $5.30.

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Optibase Ltd. OBAS, +0.00% shares rose 7.4% to $2.90 in Monday morning trade after the Israel-based provider of digital video services reported a third-quarter net loss of $589,000, or 4 cents a share, vs. $176,000, or a penny a share, last year. Revenue fell to $4.3 million from $5 million. "This quarter we saw a number of encouraging signs from carriers and operators in Europe, Asia and North America," said Chief Financial Officer Danny Lustiger in a statement. "There were a number of important developments and achievements for Optibase that helped our positioning in the IPTV market and we enter the fourth quarter with a healthy backlog."
title: Optibase shares rise on third-quarter results

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Optibase, OBAS, +0.00% a Herzliya, Israel, provider of video streaming solutions, said Palestine Telecommunications, the telecom provider to the Palestinian Authority, adopted its streaming platform to deliver live news during the PA's elections Jan. 9. PalTel stationed Optibase's encoding and streaming stations in Gaza, Nablus, Ramallah and Bethlehem to deliver video feeds from these sites during the elections, Optibase said. The video feeds were transported over a Nortel NT SDH network. Optibase shares rose 17 cents, or 3 percent, Tuesday to $5.89.
title: Israel's Optibase gets pact from Palestine Telecom

content: Among the companies scheduled to release their latest numbers on Tuesday, Digene DIGE is expected to report breakeven results for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003, according to the average consensus of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Dollar Tree Stores DLTR, -0.23% is anticipated to report a second-quarter profit of 24 cents a share. First-quarter fiscal 2004 results are due out from H&R Block HRB, -0.43% ; the company is expected to post a profit of a penny per share. Myriad Genetics MYGN, +0.10% is expected to report a 22-cent per-share loss for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003. AmeriCredit ACF, -11.11% said late Monday that for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2003, the provider of auto loans lost $17.1 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with restated net income of $90.8 million, or $1 per share, the year before. The latest results include a pre-tax, non-cash impairment charge of $57.7 million. Sales were $197.3 million for the period versus restated revenue of $309.7 million. On Aug. 6., AmeriCredit delayed the release of the latest results, noting that its accounting was undergoing an independent audit to examine how certain interest rate swaps were accounted for. Standard & Poor's Ratings Services lowered its long-term counterparty credit rating on the company to 'B' from 'B+' after the release of restated earnings. S&P also removed AmeriCredit's ratings from CreditWatch, where it was placed on Aug. 7. The outlook is negative. Shares fell 10 cents to change hands at $8.55. Gart Sports, reported third-quarter earnings that were hurt by its recently-completed merger with Sports Authority TSA, +3.32% See full story. The company's shares fell 28 cents in after-hours trading, to $29.74. Liberty Media L, -0.68% said it was taking itself out of the running for Vivendi's V, -1.02% properties. In a statement, Liberty indicated the $14 billion price tag for Vivendi was too high. See full story. Shares of Liberty rose 2.6 percent in late dealings, to $11.65. Vivendi shares did not trade after the bell. Siebel Systems SEBL told analysts on a Monday afternoon conference call that the business software company plans to take a third-quarter earnings charge in the range of $80 million to $100 million, mostly to pay for facilities cutbacks, and severance associated with 490 job cuts - about 465 of which already have been made. See full story. Shares of Siebel fell 5 cents to $10.05. Wright Medical Group WMGI, +0.30% shares edged higher in late dealings after releasing a statement at the close of markets indicating that it had complied with all requests made by the Food and Drug Administration in a recent letter concerning parts used in ceramic hips. The company also said that it does not expect any further action on its part will be required related to this matter and that it has not experienced any impact to date, nor does it anticipate any future impact, with respect to its ability to supply ceramic hip components to its U.S. customers as a result of this regulatory matter. Wright shares added 17 cents to change hands for $23.99. Amerco UHAEQ parent of trucking company U-Haul, reported its full-year fiscal 2003 results and restated results for 2001 and 2002, posting losses for all three. For 2001, the company is now showing a loss of $47.4 million vs. previously-reported earnings of $2.7 million. For 2002, the restated results showed a loss of $42.1 million vs. a profit of $1 million. For the full-year 2003, Amerco said it lost $25 million, or $1.83 per share. The restatements centered on insurance and equity accounting for the losses of Private Mini Storage Realty. Amerco said it expects first-quarter results for fiscal 2003 to come in above last year's profit of $23.8 million, but below analyst expectations. Amerco filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on June 20. Shares ended Monday up 6 cents at $11.99. Computer Associates CA, -1.36% said late Monday that it plans to settle outstanding accounting-related lawsuits against it, resulting in a second-quarter charge of about 17 cents a share. As part of the settlement, the software company said it plans to issue up to 5.7 million shares of common stock to the shareholders represented in three class-action lawsuit against the firm. As a result, the company said it will take a pre-tax charge of about $144 million for the current quarter. After taxes, the charge is expected to work out to about 17 cents a share. Computer Associates stock closed Monday down 22 cents, at $24.78. New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced Monday that his office has reached a settlement with seven of the 10 firms that signed onto the $1.4 billion Wall Street resolution which aimed to clean up Wall Street research. In April, the 10 banks involved in the $1.4 billion resolution had signed agreements with the state or states that were investigating them. New York was assigned Citigroup C, +0.96% and Morgan Stanley MWD, -1.12% and had previously reached an agreement with Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% Spitzer said Monday that the state of New York will receive $12.4 million from the seven remaining banks, most of which it has already collected. Monday's advancers Shares of Audible ADBL leapt nearly 29 percent after the provider of Web-based spoken audio services announced the signing of a new marketing alliance with Net-based retailing giant Amazon AMZN, -4.03% The new non-exclusive alliance follows the completion of the original marketing pact, which was signed in January 2000. Shares closed up 28.7 percent at $1.30. Infospace INSP, -20.00% shares gained more than 7 percent following news that the broadband Internet services firm could receive about $247 million after a federal judge in Seattle ruled late Friday against the company's founder and former CEO. In a May ruling, the court found Naveen Jain had engaged in illegal "short swing" trading. Under federal securities laws, the money Jain made illegally must be repaid to the company. See full story. Shares ended higher by 7.2 percent at $16.07. Invivo SAFE, +0.13% shares leapt more than 9 percent after the comapny declared a three-for-two split of its common stock. The split will be paid on Sept. 26 to shareholders of record on Sept. 12. Shares of the Pleasanton, Calif., maker of medical monitoring equipment finished the session at $21.25, up 9.4 percent. Shares of Metrologic Instruments MTLG added more than 17 percent after the optical image processing company raised its financial outlook for the third quarter and the full year due to stronger-than-expected demand for its scanners and increased profitability resulting from the success of cost reduction efforts. The company now expects to earn 20 to 23 cents a share on revenue of $31 million to $32 million in the third quarter, versus the average analyst projection of 18 cents and $31 million, respectively. For the full year, Metrologic expects to earn 94 to 99 cents a share on revenue of $130 million to $132 million, versus respective analyst forecasts of 90 cents and $131.4 million. Shares closed up 17.1 percent at $37.27. Optibase Ltd. OBAS, +0.00% shares gained more than 6 percent after the company was selected to deliver television and music content for Venus Telephone Co. Optibase will use its MGWE 5100 carrier grade TV streaming platform to provide 130 channels to Venus subscribers over telephone lines. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Venus operates in Clarion County, Pa. Shares closed at $6, up 6.2 percent. Shares of Sequenom SQNM gained more than 12 percent after the genetics firm disclosed discovery of several "significant" diabetes risk genes. "The targets we have identified thus far represent the most complete portfolio of diabetes risk genes ever assembled, shedding light on the important role of genetics in the development of diabetes," said Dr. Andi Braun, Sequenom's chief medical officer. "These novel targets present an excellent opportunity to develop new diagnostics and therapeutics for diabetes." Shares added 12.5 percent to close at $3.06. Track Data TRAC, +0.00% added more than 19 percent after the Web-based trading and financial market data services provider said it would pay its first cash dividend. The payment of a penny a share will be made on Sept. 22 to shareholders of record on Sept. 8. The company said it would consider future semi-annual dividends. Shares of Track Data closed at $1.50, up 19 percent. Monday's decliners Biovail VRX, -2.73% slumped more than 2 percent after the company said late Friday that the federal Department of Health and Human Services has begun a preliminary investigation of the pharmaceutical company's clinical and marketing programs for the heart medication Cardizem LA. See full story. Shares ended down 2.5 percent at $38.25. FleetBoston FBF, -11.49% shares fell more than 2 percent after Prudential lowered its rating on the stock to "sell" from "hold," telling clients that the financial company is not performing well enough to justify holding the shares in the wake of weak revenue prospects. Explaining the reasons behind the downgrade, Prudential analyst Michael Mayo said he believes Fleet is "less of a takeover target" and that its quality of earnings are lackluster, raising questions about sustainability. Internet Initiative Japan IIJI, -1.48% shares lost more than 12 percent to $3.84 in morning action. The Tokyo-based provider of Internet access services said before the opening bell that Akio Onishi has resigned from its board of directors, effective August 20, for personal reasons. The stock continues to freefall after dropping roughly 40 percent last week as Crosswave Communications CWCIQ which Internet Initiative Japan holds a 37.9 percent stake in, filed for bankruptcy protection. At the time, Internet Initiative said it believes the filing will "seriously impact" its financial position and operations. Crosswave provides a significant portion of Internet Initiative Japan's network, data center, and telecommunications facilities, and it owes IIJI roughly 1.72 billion yen in loans. Internet Initiative shares dropped 12.4 percent to close at $3.94. Liquidmetal Technologies' LQMT, -5.47% fell more than 23 percent after Robert W. Baird dropped its rating on the stock to "underperform" from "neutral," citing diminished growth expectations. The firm, which also lowered its price target to $2 from $6, said it's no longer comfortable with the assumption that growth will be "extremely rapid" once early adopters of the company's amorphous alloys and coatings became customers. It also said news that Motorola MSI, -0.81% will not become a customer until 2004 at the earliest is a negative. Shares lost 23.3 percent to end at $3.76. LookSmart's LOOK, -1.02% stock slid more than 4 percent after the company said William Lonergan would be its chief financial officer, effective Sept. 22. Lonergan was most recently the CFO of Tacit Knowledge Systems, and spent 20 years as a senior partner at KPMG before that. Lonergan will replace Dianne Dubois, who announced on May 27 plans to resign for family reasons and to pursue other interests. Shares fell 4.6 percent to close at $3.35. McData MCDTA shares dropped 18 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $9.1 million, or 8 cents a share, versus a loss of $3.9 million, or 3 cents a share in the year-earlier period amid a 13.8 percentage point improvement in gross margin, which resulted from stronger volumes and product mix. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 7 cents a share, on average. Revenue increased 39 percent to $107 million, but just missed analyst forecasts of $108.8 million. Looking ahead, the data storage firm expects to earn 5 to 7 cents a share on revenue of $105 million to $110 million in its fiscal third quarter, versus analyst projections of 7 cents and $112.9 million, respectively. Separately, the company said it acquired privately-held Nishan Systems and Sanera Systems for an undisclosed amount. McData expects the acquisitions to dilute third quarter earnings by 3 cents a share. Shares of McData finished down 17.9 percent at $10.40. Pegasus Communications' PGTV shares tumbled more than 11 percent after the company opted to terminate plans for a senior term loan financing originally announced in late July. "While we will continue to be opportunistic in evaluating means to improve our balance sheet, for now we are comfortable to retain the flexibility and pricing afforded by our current senior credit facility," said the Bala Cynwyd, Pa., provider of digital satellite television services in a press release. Shares lost 11.1 percent to end at $18.68. Rediff.com REDF shares slid more than 6 percent after the India-based Web services firm said Rick Filippelli would resign effective Sept. 5. The company named Joy Basu, its current vice president of finance, to replace Filippelli in the CFO role. Rediff.com stock fell 6.3 percent to end the session at $4.76. Universal Display PANL, -4.53% dropped more than 6 percent after the Ewing, N.J., flat panel display technology firm said it has received commitments to purchase up to $16.1 million worth of its common stock. The company plans to sell up to 2,012,500 common shares for $8 each to certain institutional investors. It expects the deal to close on August 28. Shares closed at $8.40, down 6.7 percent. Western Digital WDC, -0.94% shares fell more than 3 percent after the company said it would make a one-time payment of $45 million to Cirrus Logic CRUS, -1.77% as part of a settlement of a contract dispute. The data storage company had previously estimated the obligation related to the dispute to be $26.5 million, and therefore will record a charge of the difference - $18.5 million - in the fourth quarter. Western Digital's shares closed down 3.6 percent at $8.92. content: Stocks to Watch Allied Waste Industries (AW: news, chart, profile) said it expects third-quarter earnings and revenue will be "essentially flat" compared with the second quarter, citing economic indicators that show the economy has worsened. The company anticipates there will not be an increase in disposal volumes in the third quarter. In the second quarter, earnings totaled 22 cents a share, with revenue of $1.41 billion. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect a third-quarter profit of 27 cents a share. As a result of the weak conditions, the company anticipates 2001 EBITDA to be 3 to 4 percent below the previously indicated guidance minimum of $2.075 billion. Shares slipped 54 cents to $17.21 ahead of the news. Amazon.com AMZN, -4.14% and Target Corp. TGT, -0.46% are expected to form a partnership to jointly sell goods over the Internet, the Wall Street Journal reported in its online edition Tuesday. In a short release Monday, ExciteAtHome (ATHM: news, chart, profile) said its CFO Mark McEachen resigned and "will leave the company to pursue other opportunities." Excite said it's seeking a new CFO. Shares rose 3 cents to 42 cents ahead of the announcement. H.J. Heinz HNZ is also reporting earnings Tuesday. The analyst consensus is for earnings of 61 cents a share. Shares were off 31 cents at $45.51. Luxury department store retailer Neiman Marcus Group NMG is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter results Tuesday. Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call expect the company to report a loss of 31 cents a share. Shares closed down 63 cents at $30.25. Late Monday, Northrop Grumman Corp. NOC, -0.03% reiterated the financial targets that it outlined in July when it reported second-quarter results. Northrop said it still sees 2001 sales exceeding $13 billion, 2002 sales of roughly $16 billion and 2003 sales of roughly $18 billion. Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer (PFE: news, chart, profile) said it's reaffirming earlier earnings targets for 2001 and 2002. The New York-based drugmaker said it expects earnings from continuing operations of $1.27 per share to $1.30 per share for 2001 and earnings from continuing operations in 2002 of $1.56 per share "or better." The maker of anti-impotence drug Viagra was expected to earn $1.30 per share in 2001 and $1.59 per share in 2002, according to the average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. Shares of Pfizer gained $1.17 to close at $38.17. Walt Disney DIS, -0.49% would oppose any combination of AOL Time Warner and AT&T's cable-television business unless the merged company sold all of its content holdings, the Wall Street Journal reported in its online edition Tuesday. Xilinx (XLNX: news, chart, profile) reiterated that it expects second-quarter revenue to be down 20 to 25 percent compared with the first quarter total of $289.3 million. Analysts polled by First Call currently expect revenue of about $224 million. Xilinx said it will take an inventory write-down in the range of $65 million and $85 million in the second quarter, mainly in relation to its Virtex and Virtex-E FPGA products. Xilinx said there was decreased demand for those products. Excluding the write-down, the company expects gross margin to track slightly ahead of the 50 to 52 percent guidance for the September quarter. Read full story. Shares closed down 29 cents at $36.96. Advancers American Coin Merchandising AMCN, -6.35% soared more than 36 percent after the company agreed to be acquired for $125 million, including debt assumption, by a newly formed corporation made up of Wellspring Capital Management and Knightsbridge Holdings. The deal values shares of the Boulder, Colo., operator of amusement vending machines at $8.50 each, a 42 percent premium to its Friday closing price of $5.96. Shares closed up $2.12 at $8.08. American Tower AMT, -0.03% added more than 4 percent after the Boston wireless communications site operator denied a report in The Observer, a London newspaper, that it has made an offer to purchase NTL's NLI, +2.00% aerials and transmission business this weekend. American Tower, whose shares slid last week after the company discussed its debt in an 8-K filing with the SEC, added that it does not plan to participate in bidding for NTL's tower assets or to enter the European market. Shares of NTL closed off 45 cents at $11.45. AOL Time Warner AOL rose 7 percent following a Wall Street Journal report that it has made an offer to for AT&T's T, -0.81% cable television division. Shares ended the day up $2.13 at $34.41. Anadigics ANAD gained 19 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter revenue of $16 million, better than its previously disclosed outlook. The company pegged its loss for the period at 56 to 58 cents a share, reflecting a shift in its sales mix toward wireless products. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are currently looking for a loss of 55 cents a share in the September quarter. For the fourth quarter, the Warren, N.J., provider of radio frequency integrated circuit products expects revenue of $18 million to $18.5 million. Anadigics continues to target a 30 percent reduction in expenses by the first quarter of 2002 and expects to return to profitability in the second half of 2002. Shares were up $2.30 at $14.15. Beyond.com BYND soared 46 percent in late action. After hitting an all-time low of 77 cents in intraday trading on Aug. 30, the stock has closed higher ever since, and is poised to stretch its winning steak to 8 sessions. The software reseller was not immediately available for comment. Shares closed up 95 cents at $3.00. Cantel Medical CNTL leapt $3.61, or 20 percent to $22.10. Before the opening bell on Friday, the Little Falls, N.J., healthcare products firm announced the completion of its merger with Minntech, whose shareholders received $6.25 in cash and .2216 of a Cantel share for each Minntech share held. The deal was announced on May 31. At that time, the consideration was valued at $10.50 per share based on Cantel's May 30 closing price of $23, but the exchange ratio was not announced until August 29. Community Savings Bankshares CMSV surged more than 28 percent after it agreed to by acquired by BankAtlantic Bancorp BBX, +0.00% for approximately $170 million. Community shareholders will receive $19 per share in cash, a 31-percent premium to Friday's closing price of $14.50, and 16 percent above its 52-week high of $16.35. Once the deal is completed, which is expected to be in the first quarter of 2002, BankAtlantic will be the largest financial institution headquartered in Florida, with approximately $5.7 billion in assets. Community shares closed up $4.12 at $18.62. BankAtlantic shares edged up 6 cents at $9.09. ESpeed ESPD added 9 percent after the company said it would write down its investments in Visible Markets and QV Trading Systems resulting in a third-quarter non-cash charge of $3.8 million, or 7 cents a share. According to a statement, ESpeed, an operator of electronic marketplaces, will write off its entire $3 million investment in Visible Markets and it will write down its $800,000 investment in QV. Shares rose 74 cents to $8.69. Global Power Equipment GEG, -7.46% advanced 7 percent after the company said it's comfortable with Wall Street expectations for earnings of 23 cents a share in the third quarter and 24 cents a share in the fourth quarter. The Tulsa, Okla., maker of gas turbine equipment also said it's comfortable with estimates of profits of 90 cents a share in fiscal 2001 and $1.13 a share in fiscal 2002. Shares were up $1.07 at $16.39. Helen of Troy Ltd. HELE, -2.53% rose 8 percent after the company reconfirmed its financial projections for the second quarter and full year. The El Paso, Texas, consumer products firm said it expects to meet or exceed its outlook for earnings of 17 to 19 cents a share on sales of more than $100 million in the second quarter, and earnings of 80 to 90 cents a share on sales of more than $400 million to $415 million in the full year. Helen of Troy said actual sales for the second quarter were in the range of $105 million to $110 million. Shares ended up 93 cents at $12.17. InfoSpace INSP, -20.00% added 6 percent after the Bellevue, Wash., provider of Internet consumer and commerce services agreed to buy back 21.7 million of its shares from Vulcan Ventures. The company said it made the purchase at a discount to the current trading price of the stock and that it plans to retire the shares. In addition, InfoSpace announced a deal to provide its Authorize.net online payments service to Union Bank of California. Financial terms weren't disclosed. The stock closed up 8 cents at $1.40. Louis Dreyfus Natural Gas LD, +0.00% jumped 11 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Dominion Resources D, +0.27% for $2.3 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt. The deal calls for shareholders of the Oklahoma City-based Louis Dreyfus to receive $20 cash and 0.3226 of a share of Dominion stock for each share held. Richmond, Va.-based Dominion is also assuming $505 million in Louis Dreyfus debt. Dominion also reaffirmed that it expects to meet or exceed its 2001 earnings outlook of about $4.15 per share, its 2002 earnings outlook of $4.85 to $4.90 per share. Dominion shares rose $5.72 to $38.68. Dominion shares were down $2.37, or 4 percent at $60.26. Proxim PROX, +0.00% advanced 11 percent after the company announced that its Stratum wireless broadband product platform has been deployed by P&O Princess Cruises in the Southampton area of the United Kingdom. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Some of the interest in the stock may be attributable to positive announcements from wireless communications firms RF Micro and Anadigics. Shares closed higher by $1.23 at $12.60. Qwest Q, +0.32% added $1.76, or 10 percent before closing at $19.90. The company's stock plumbed a 52-week low of $16.28 in the initial market reaction to its news of a revenue warning, 4,000 job-cuts, and reduced capital spending plans. RF Micro Devices RFMD rose 42 cents to $22.73 after the company said financial results for the second quarter would "significantly exceed" previous forecasts due to market share gains, increased end-user demand and normalized inventory levels. The maker of wireless communications chips said it anticipates breaking even for the quarter ending September, while analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had been expecting the company to lose 4 cents a share, on average. The company now expects revenue to be approximately $91 million, compared to analyst forecasts of $77.8 million. Revenue for the fiscal third quarter should exceed $91 million, versus analyst views of $89.1 million. Sonic Corp. SONC, +0.20% tacked on more than 5 percent after the company said that same-store sales came in "slightly ahead" of its targeted range for 2 to 4 percent growth in the fourth quarter. The Oklahoma City drive-in restaurant firm also said it remains comfortable with Wall Street expectations for earnings of $1.39 per share in fiscal 2001. Sonic opened 191 new restaurants in 2001. For fiscal 2002, the company is targeting ongoing same-store sales growth of 2 to 4 percent, opening 190 to 200 restaurants, and 18 to 20 percent growth in earnings per share. Shares were up $1.38 at $29.44. Yahoo YHOO gained 79 cents, or 28 cents to $11.74. U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray analyst Safa Rashtchy issued a bullish note on the firm Monday, saying he believes Yahoo will meet estimates for the third quarter. Rashtchy, who has a "buy" rating on the shares, thinks that the stock price - which has fallen more than 40 percent since the beginning of August - has "more to do with longer term worries" than the company's ability to post a profit of a penny a share on revenue of roughly $171.3 million for the September quarter as analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are predicting. Rashtchy reasons that the stock has fallen so quickly due to these long-term concerns about the overall market and that as a leader on the Internet, the shares will rebound quicker when the market begins to improve. "While we don't know if the market is growing to show any signs of improvement any time soon, we do expect Yahoo to have positive announcements in the next few weeks leading to its earnings release Oct. 10th," he writes. Decliners Avici Systems AVCI plummeted 28 percent after the company lowered third-quarter revenue estimates to $9 million to $10 million from $22.5 million to $23.5 million, as market conditions have resulted in lower-than-anticipated customer orders. Per shares losses are expected to be 40 to 42 cents a share, while analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had been expecting a loss of 23 cents a share, on average. The Internet router maker added that it would reduce its workforce by 14 percent, or approximately 55 employees. Shares fell 79 cents to $1.99. Beacon Power BCON tripped 9 percent after the company disclosed that it has withdrawn 100 units valued at $1.5 billion from backlog. These units were included in its Dec. 31 backlog but no revenue was recognized related to them. The company also said its relationship with TLER Associates, the customer related to the units, has ended. Beacon also lowered its unit forecast for 2001 to 20 units from 50. Shares were down 25 cents at $2.55. Blockbuster BBI, -3.85% slid more than 8 percent after the Dallas movie rental firm said it would accelerate plans to "capitalize on the long-term profitability associated with the higher margin DVD rental market." In relation to these plans - which call for expansion of the DVD section in its stores, re-merchandising to highlight the digital format, and sales of DVD players in stores worldwide - the company said it would eliminate roughly 25 percent of its VHS inventory as well as select video games and drop the residual value of all VHS tapes and games to $2 and $5, respectively. These moves are expected to result in the company recording a charge of roughly $450 million in the third quarter. Looking ahead, Blockbuster said it expects rental margins to be enhanced by continued growth of DVD as a rental format. Shares fell $1.64 to $18.35. Centra Software CTRA, +1.28% slumped $2.15, or 19 percent to $9.00 after Needham & Co. lowered its rating on shares of the Lexington, Mass., e-learning firm to "hold" from "buy." The firm said it thinks Centra "will be challenged to meet these estimates given the current market environment." The call was part of a wider industry call on the e-learning industry, which included downgrades of DigitalThink DTHK Docent DCNT SkillSoft SKIL SmartForce SMTF all of which were cut to "hold" from "buy." Sellers responded in force: SkillSoft lost more than 15 percent, SmartForce rose 6 cents to $24.03. Docent sank 32 cents, or 9 percent to $3.08. DigitalThink slipped a penny to $10.20. Circuit City Group CC, -3.00% tripped $1.18, or 9 percent to $18.90, extending a drop of more than 20 percent Friday after the company reported disappointing sales for the second quarter. Jefferies is out with a research note Monday reiterating its "accumulate" rating on the company at these levels, saying it continues to expect the stock to trade within a range of $16 to $18 on the upside and $10 to $12 on the downside. The firm said the issue "still has some appeal as a value stock" but added that it has little confidence in its own ability to predict earnings for Circuit City because of the company's ongoing remodeling initiatives. Jefferies explained the reaction to the second-quarter figures was extreme because there was "considerable buzz" suggesting that the same-store sales figures "would not really be that bad." Coventry Health CV.H, +0.00% lost 9 percent after Prudential Securities lowered its rating on the company's stock to "sell" from "hold." The firm also cut Humana HUM, +5.49% similarly, while upgrading the HMO industry in general, and Trigon TGH, -2.06% WellPoint WLP and HealthNet HNT, +0.00% specifically. All three companies received upgrades to "buy" from "sell" based on their "strong underwriting positions and lower relative valuations." Coventry and Humana were cut for precisely the same reasons, namely Prudential's determination that the companies have higher relative valuations and higher underwriting risk. Prudential added that while it remains concerned about the underwriting cycle, its apprehension about potential political/legal risk have "abated somewhat" because the climate is turning "decidedly milder under the Bush Administration." Coventry shares closed down $1.80 at $18.90. Dobson Communications DCEL sank 20 percent after Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown analyst Jeff Hines lowered his rating on the Oklahoma City wireless phone services firm to "market perform" from "strong buy," to reflect the increased risk and uncertainty that shareholder face given the controlling shareholder's pledge of 53.6 million shares as collateral for a $290 million loan. Dobson shares jumped in early action Friday after the company hired Banc of America and Lehman Bros. to assist in exploring its strategic options. But after rising as high as $17.19, the stock sold off and closed down more than 5 percent at $14.08. "Now does not seem to be an appropriate time to be looking to maximize value for shareholders via a sale of Telecom assets," Hines said in a note to clients. "Given the current state of the market and apparent financial health of the controlling shareholder, one cannot see how Dobson is in a position of strength in any such negotiations." Shares were off $2.87 at $11.21. Idex IEX, -0.97% dropped 12 percent after the Northbrook, Ill., maker of pumps and metering products lowered its earnings expectations for the third quarter. The company anticipates it will report a profit of 25 to 30 cents a share in the period, below Wall Street expectations for a profit of 45 cents a share. Idex cited weaker-than-expected business conditions in the U.S. and some international markets. Specifically, the company said July orders were the lowest this year, and that while August did improve somewhat, they were still under the first-half average. Shares ended down $4.11 at $30.50. J.C. Penney JCP, +2.32% fell 5 percent after the company said it would privately sell approximately $500 million of convertible notes, subject to market conditions. The notes will be convertible into J.C. Penney common stock at a price to be determined. The retailer said it would use the proceeds of the offering primarily for upcoming debt maturities. Shares fell $1.22 to $23.00. Optibase OBAS, +0.00% dropped 14 percent after the Israeli provider of broadband media products disclosed plans to reduce its international workforce by 15 percent. The company said the move is part of an effort to "strengthen its legacy product line" and "ensure" its economic performance. Shares closed down 44 cents at $2.61. PolyMedica PLMD edged down 22 cents to $12.78 after the company reaffirmed its revenue outlook of $68 million to $69 million for the second quarter ending September 30, and $275 million for fiscal 2002. The Woburn, Mass., medical device firm said its core business remains strong with "increased demand for diabetes and respiratory supplies from a growing base of loyal customers." However, PolyMedica said it would not be able to provide an earnings outlook due to its expectations that it will incur "unusual legal and related expenses in the current quarter" estimated at 10 to 14 cents per share from the federal investigation of its Liberty Medical Supply and Liberty Home Pharmacy units. In addition, PolyMedica said it has received administrative overpayment notices from a durable medical equipment regional carrier, or DMERC. The company said it expects to expense $800,000 to $1 million related to the notices in the current quarter. Noting that it uses the same pricing formula for albuterol and ipratropium with three other DMERCs, PolyMedica said it could expense up to an additional $5 million to $5.5 million if these companies were to take the same position. Roadhouse Grill GRLL plunged 56 percent after it re-opened for the first time since August 1 when the company announced it would have to restate prior financial results due to accounting errors. On August 15, the Pompano Beach, Fla., casual dining firm reported its fourth-quarter and full-year results, and noted that its auditors had issued an opinion that there is substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern in light of its "significant cash flow problems, the net loss for fiscal 2001 and defaults under certain of the company's loan facilities, covenants, and payment provisions." Shares were off 75 cents at 60 cents. ScottishPower SPI, -0.12% sank 9 percent after the company said that the recent collapse in electricity prices in the western U.S. would result in additional excess net power costs of roughly $300 million at its PacifiCorp operations. ScottishPower said that PacifiCorp's contribution to its earnings for the year to March 2002 "will reduce by nine pence per share." The company added that management is working to mitigate risk and improve processes and that PacifiCorp plans to seek regulatory recovery of allowable excess net power costs. Shares closed down $2.35 at $25.45. Steel Dynamics STLD, -0.93% tumbled 8 percent after Morgan Stanley Dean Witter lowered its rating on shares of the Fort Wayne, Ind., firm to "neutral" from "outperform" due to disappointing pricing trends. "2001 price increases have failed and gains should be modest in 2002, we anticipate," the firm said in a research note to clients. "We believe that it may take all of 2002 and perhaps part of 2003 for the industry to secure the price increases that are currently in the marketplace." The firm also lowered earnings estimates on the company for 2001 through 2003. USX X, -1.56% which Morgan already rates "neutral," had its estimates cut by the firm for the same reasons. Steel Dynamics was off $1.19 at $12.90. USX ended down 93 cents, or 5 percent at $17.00. Tellium TELM, +0.00% dove $1.82, or 21 percent to $17.00. Harry Carr, the chairman and CEO for the Oceanport, N.J., optical switching technology firm, attributed the selling to news that one of its customers, Qwest, plans to curtail capital spending. He told CBS MarketWatch this concern was unwarranted. "We spoke to Qwest today and based on the conversation, we're confident that going forward we are going to be one of the company's supplier in both the near-term and the long-term." Saying that business is "great" at Tellium, Carr also reaffirmed the company's confidence in its goal for revenue of $125 million to $135 million in 2001, which it disclosed when it reported second-quarter results on July 18. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are looking for a loss of 16 cents a share in the September quarter Tellium went public on May 17, offering 9 million shares at $15 each in its well-received debut. The stock rose as high as $29.73 on May 22. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Stephen Hawkingâ€™s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Donâ€™t ever do this with your credit card Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch: Pfizer, Xilinx, Allied Waste and more

content: Stocks to Watch California Micro Devices CAMD said it expects third-quarter earnings to be 10 percent to 20 percent lower than expected on revenue 8 percent to 10 percent lower than the previous quarter. California Micro said revenue has been pulled down by industry-wide order cancellations and pushouts in personal computers, networking and telecom industries. California Micro was expected to report earnings of 14 cents a share. See full story. California Micro shares rose 13 cents to $7.44. Openwave Systems Inc., OPWV and Geoworks Corp. GWRX a mobile communications company, will settle their patent dispute with a royalty-free patent cross-license deal. Openwave will be able use some of Geoworks' patented technology. Both companies agreed to seek dismissals of all litigation between them. Openwave receives a worldwide license to Geoworks' Flexible User Interface patent and a second patent from Geoworks' patent portfolio to be selected by Openwave over the next 18 months. Geoworks will get an Openwave patent and will select another during the next 18 months. Openwave shares closed up $2.94, or 6.4 percent, to $48.81. Geoworks shares closed up 19 cents, or 15 percent, to $1.41. See full story. Breakaway Solutions BWAY said fourth-quarter losses will be wider than the current consensus estimate on Wall Street. The company expects a loss between 26 cents and 28 cents, while analysts currently expect a loss of 5 cents. The company anticipates that its fourth-quarter revenues will be in a range of about $22.5 million to $24 million. The company cited a sharp decline in business from Internet Capital Group ICGE companies and a move away from Internet firms as customers. Breakaway will also bump up its job cuts to 30 percent of its workforce, from a previously announced level of 10 percent. Breakaway shares were not active after closing unchanged at $1. Net Perceptions NETP said it expects fourth-quarter net losses of $9.5 million to $11 million, or 36 cents to 41 cents a share, on revenue of $6.3 million to $7.3 million. Analysts surveyed by First Call expected losses of 29 cents a share, on average. According to a company statement, customers delayed buying products and higher costs were incurred due to reorganization. Net Perceptions expects to finish the year with $96 million in cash. Net Perceptions shares were not active after closing up 25 cents, or 14 percent, to $2.06. Optibase OBAS, +0.00% said late Thursday it expects lower sales to cut into profit, resulting in a breakeven bottom line. Citing a weak technology sector, the company said it expects fourth-quarter revenue in the range of $6.8 million and $7.3 million, on a consolidated basis. In particular, the company said sales of its MediaGateway2000 product should hit $1 million, double expectations. Looking ahead to 2001, the company forecasts per-share earnings for the year in the range of 5 cents to 25 cents because of the impact of research and development costs. As well the company said its board authorized a 1 million share buyback program. Shares of the multimedia software specialist closed up 28 cents to $7.25. Information Holdings IHI, -1.52% said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of 10 cents to 12 cents a share on revenue of $22 million to $23 million. IHI closed up $3.88, or 22 percent, to $21.75. Credit card provider Providian PVN, +0.00% said Thursday it will settle consumer class action cases in a California Superior Court in San Francisco and the Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. As a result, the San-Francisco-based company will take a $22 million fourth-quarter charge, or 7 cents a share, to cover the settlements over some of its marketing practices. The company maintains it is on target for its fourth-quarter profit and will report earnings in a range of 71 cents to 73 cents a share. Shares of Providian ended up $3.25 to $53. Advancers Barrett Resources BRR, +8.20% added 3 percent after FAC/Equities analyst Robert L. Christensen Jr. reiterated a "strong buy" recommendation and established a $109 target price. Christensen cited Marathon Oil's takeover of Pennaco Energy as a positive for other Power River Basin coal bed methane producers. He said that based on Marathon's bid, Barrett's coal bed methane position could be "conservatively" worth $25 a share and Barrett's Power River Basin acreage could be worth $40 to $50 a share. Barrett shares rose $1.69 to $57.13. Biolase Technology BLTI rose more than 24 percent after the company said it has no explanation for the recent weakness in its stock price, which fell more than 30 percent Tuesday. However, the company said sales of its Waterlase dental laser are "very strong." For the fourth quarter, Biolase said it expects sales in excess of $3 million, resulting in break-even to slightly positive cash flow. Biolase Technology gained 16 cents to $1.31. Blue Martini BLUE, -4.39% gained 16 percent after the company signed a collaborative pact with Intel INTC, -1.94% The companies plan to work together on engineering, marketing and sales activities. Shares rose $2.19 to $15.50. See full story. Cal-Maine Foods CALM, -4.35% jumped 14 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of 35 cents a share, up from last year's loss of 22 cents a share. The company said egg prices remain good as it enters the third quarter with feed prices up moderately from a year ago. Cal-Maine shares rose 81 cents to $6.13. Christopher & Banks CHBS added more than 4 percent after the company reported a 12 percent increase in same-store sales in December. The retailer said it continues to see robust selling at full price. Christopher & Banks gained $1.50 to $28.50. CoreComm Ltd. COMM, -1.28% soared more than 40 percent after the company said members of its management and board of directors have invested $16 million in the company in the form of a convertible note. CoreComm plans to use the funds for working capital and general corporate purposes. CoreComm ended the day up $1.06 to $3.69. Cyber-Care CYBR, -0.65% leapt 13 percent after the company said it has received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market its blood glucose monitoring system. The company plans to integrate the product with its electronic house-call system. Shares gained 28 cents to $2.38. Drovers Bancshares DROV advanced more than 22 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Fulton Financial FULT, -1.13% for $144.4 million in stock. The deal calls for Fulton to swap 1.24 common shares for each Drovers' share. Fulton shares lost 6 percent on the news. Drovers Bancshares ended up $5.19 to $26.44. EPlus PLUS, -1.80% soared 57 percent after the Internet software and services company said it will post a greater-than-expected profit in its third and fourth quarters. The company said it will report third-quarter per-share earnings of 16 cents, 45 percent above the consensus estimate of 11 cents. Looking to the fourth quarter, the company expects to earn 16 cents a share, an increase of 60 percent from the expected target. Shares rose $4.38 to $12.13. InKine Pharmaceutical INKP, +0.91% advanced 17 percent after the company received a patent for non-aqueous colonic purgative formulations. One of the inventors was InKine Chairman and CEO Leonard S. Jacob. The patent covers compositions containing effective amounts of orally administered colonic purgative salts, as well as broad coverage for purgation of the colon to prepare it for a diagnostic or surgical procedure. At the end of the day, InKine shares closed up $1 to $6.81. Micromuse MUSE rose more than 8 percent after Lehman Bros. issued a research note on the San Francisco provider of real-time fault management software, noting its recent pact with Williams Communications WCG, -0.25% is a positive. The firm reiterated its "buy" rating on Micromuse, noting its easy deployment and the fact that it won this contract over 15 other vendors. "Another software license transaction, another happy customer, and another opportunity to sell future Netcool offerings," the note reads. Shares rose $4.94 to $63.50. Radware RDWR, -0.37% leapt more 16 percent after the company said it feels comfortable with Wall Street expectations for the fourth quarter and full year. Radware made the announcement after several competitors announced warnings. A First Call survey of four analysts forecast the company will post a profit of 9 cents a share. Shares were up $2.75 to $19.81. SmartDisk SMDK surged more than 82 percent in late action. The Naples, Fla., consumer electronics firm warned about its fourth-quarter results on Dec. 20, sending its stock to a 52-week low of $2. Daniel Reed, a spokesman for SmartDisk, said the company knows of no material reason for the jump and noted the depressed condition of the shares, which are well off a 52-week high of $67.50 on March 1. Shares were up $1.81 Thursday to $4. Symantec SYMC, -1.90% gained 14 percent after the Cupertino, Calif., provider of security software issued a press release to combat weakness in its stock following a profit warning from sector-mate Network Associates NETA Symantec expressed confidence in its future, saying its consumer business is strong and that it remains a leader in the enterprise security business. Symantec shares rose $4.31 to $35.25. Visual Networks VNWK flew more than 35 percent higher after Goldman Sachs transferred coverage of the stock and made some bullish comments about its prospects. "We believe the shares have hit their low in recent months and will incrementally move up as Visual regains traction in the network management market through its focused strategic initiatives," the firm said in a research note that transferred coverage of Visual to analyst Debra Katz and maintained its "market outperformer" rating. The company's shares rose 78 cents to $3. Decliners CacheFlow CFLO lost more than 32 percent in late action. Shares of the Sunnyvale, Calif., provider of Internet caching appliances, which manage the flow of information over the Internet, have been extremely volatile of late. On Dec. 21, the stock hit an intra-day 52 week low of $19 after falling in eight straight sessions from a close of $75.63 on Dec. 11. The company wasn't immediately available for comment. Luke Fichthorn, an analyst with Lazard Freres & Co., attributed Thursday's weakness in the stock to a warning from F5 Networks FFIV, -1.52% "The end-market demand for these companies is basically the same," said Fichthorn. CacheFlow shares fell $10.31 to $21.06. DSET Corp. DSET plunged 35 percent after the company said it expects to report a fourth-quarter loss of $11.5 million to $13.5 million, or $1 to $1.15 a share, on revenue of $4 million to $6 million. Analysts polled by First Call were looking for a profit of 2 cents a share. The company has also allocated $6.5 million in reserves for bad debts because of continued financing difficulties at several of its customers. DSET shares fell $1.13 to $2.13. See full story. Littelfuse LFUS, -2.32% lost 15 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings of 31 to 33 cents a share on sales of roughly $82 million, below Wall Street expectations. A First Call survey of seven analysts put the company's profit for the period at 37 cents a share. The Des Plaines, Ill., circuit protection product firm attributed the shortfall to the slowdown in the automotive market, moderate growth in the telecom and computer markets, and inventory adjustments by electronics distributors and contract manufacturers. content: Stocks shine after Fed hikes rates NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stocks put on a dazzling show Tuesday following news of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike, with investors dashing into financial and technology shares despite a soggy bond market. The Dow Jones Industrial Averagesprinted 171.58 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,932.33. The barometer was up 75 points just before the Fed's 2:15 p.m. ET announcement. The Nasdaq Composite skipped up 73.53 points, or 2.3 percent, to 3,293.07 for its 11th record close in 13 days. The Standard & Poor's 500 Indexrose 1.8 percent, for its first record close in four months. The Russell 2000 Index of small-capitalization stocks gained 0.9 percent. Market Snapshot Market Pulse Movers & Shakers Earnings Surprises Fed hikes rates WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- The Federal Reserve raised overnight interest rates by a quarter-percentage point Tuesday, bringing the Federal funds rate to 5.5 percent and the discount rate to 5 percent. With the rate hike, its third this year, the central bank thus removes the last of the extra liquidity it added to the money supply a year ago, when conditions in financial markets seemed so bleak as a panic swept the globe. The increase of 25 basis points will be matched almost immediately in the prime rate banks charge and eventually will be reflected in most other market interest rates, from corporate borrowing to mortgage rates. Full story Vodafone may launch hostile Mannesmann bid LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Vodafone Airtouch PLC said Tuesday that it's prepared to launch a hostile bid for Mannesmann AG, if that proves necessary, just two days after the German mobile operator rejected its British suitor. Making clear it won't be thrown so easily, Vodafone also unfurled a list of reasons as to why a marriage with Mannesmann makes sense on Tuesday. Among other things, the two would "have an unmatched European footprint," Vodafone said. It also said the combined companies would chalk up at least $820 million (500 million pounds) in savings in 2003 and $972 million (600 million pounds) in 2004. On Sunday, Mannesmann rejected a $106 billion unsolicited acquisition bid from Vodafone AirTouch, the world's biggest cellular-phone operator. Full story Pfizer renews bid for Warner-Lambert NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer, seeking to show Wall Street it offers the best match for Warner-Lambert, boosted its revenue projections and slammed rival suitor American Home Products in a meeting Tuesday with analysts. At the same time, Pfizer said it would begin seeking shareholder approval of a measure to remove Warner-Lambert's board of directors. Pfizer said such a move would allow shareholders to "consider the most advantageous transaction" available to them. Full story Comcast to acquire Lenfest for $6.7 billion PHILADELPHIA (CBS.MW) -- Comcast, in a move to solidify its grip on the Philadelphia region, said Tuesday it will buy cable operator Lenfest Communications from AT&T and the Lenfest family for $6.71 billion in stock and assumed debt. The new arrangement supercedes AT&T's previous agreement to acquire the rest of Wilmington, Del.-based Lenfest, which is already half-owned by Ma Bell. Under the terms, Comcast will exchange 116 million Class A special common shares and assume $1.5 billion of Lenfest debt. Full story Home Depot profits jump 46 percent ATLANTA (CBS.MW) -- Home Depot, the newly anointed Dow Jones Industrial Average component, posted a 46 percent advance in third-quarter earnings, the retailer said Tuesday. In the latest quarter, the company said it earned $573 million, or 37 cents a share, up from $392 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. That was 2 cents ahead of the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call Corp. Sales climbed 28 percent to $9.88 billion from $7.7 billion a year earlier. Comparable-store sales, a key measure of health in the retail sector, increased 10 percent. Home Depot said customer transactions rose by 20 percent and the average revenue per transaction rose by 7 percent. Full story Around the Web Morningstar does a good-cop-bad-cop job on foreign-stock-fund managers Tuesday, lauding them for, on average, beating the growth of the S&P 500 this year while chiding them for expense ratios that are higher than the average in any domestic-fund category. Gregg Wolper of the fund-tracking firm says managers should work to cut their costs to ensure that their funds stay as attractive to investors as they are currently and "solidify their position in the marketplace." He concedes that fund firms will trot out the excuses that travel costs are high and that it's costlier to unearth data on firms located abroad than in the United States. But Wolper argues that cut-rate airfares are available to anyone who bothers to shop and adds that other research costs have also come down. As proof, he notes that TIAA-CREF, T. Rowe Price and Hotchkis & Wiley all have international stock funds with costs of below 1 percent. The average sectorwide: 1.7 percent. Full column StockWatch: Mirage Resorts NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Mirage Resorts Chairman Steve Wynn in recent weeks has seen a billionaire, Kirk Kerkorian, walk away from his languishing casino stock -- and according to one report, pocket millions of profit in the process. Wynn's pioneering company, builder of the classy Mirage and Bellagio casinos in Las Vegas, has suffered several Wall Street downgrades. The company's spending on a Treasure Island upgrade in Vegas -- and heavy marketing spending at the new Beau Rivage casino in Mississippi -- is slimming Mirage Resorts profits even as revenue climbs smartly. Thom Calandra's StockWatch Economic convergence for China, U.S. SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) --After 13 years of talks, a deal has finally been struck under which the United States will support China's membership in the World Trade Organization. It represents a triumph of pragmatism over ideology, a process which began decades ago when Nixon and Kissinger decided to initiate a dialogue with that Communist power. Since then, the key objective for our developing relationship has been economic convergence, based on the theory that the coming together of our economic systems will inevitably lead to the necessary reforms of their political and legal systems -- that capitalism will lead to democracy and the rule of law. Paul Erdman Lock in insurance rates now WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Have you thought about investing in term life insurance but haven't gotten around to it? Better act now, because rates for many of these policies will probably go up in January. Why? Because the National Association of Insurance Commissioners (NAIC) is promoting a model regulation that will likely limit the availability and significantly increase prices of term life insurance policies whose premiums are guaranteed for more than 5 years. Full Story Loeb: Don't burn those bridges NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- If you're quitting for a new job, how should you break the bad news to your current boss? Bosses tell me that you should simply make a face-to-face announcement -- and don't try to lever it into a negotiating session for higher pay. Sure, you may get a counter-offer, but if you accept it, your boss may later resent you for extorting it from him under pressure and consider you disloyal. In too many cases, says longtime organizational consultant Robert Swain, such a maneuver is never forgiven. Marshall Loeb

content: PHILADELPHIA (Inman) -- Have you been shopping around for a home loan lately? Mortgage professor Jack Guttentag says you may have been fooled by advertised APR rates and and how effective they are for comparing mortgage prices. How useful are APR rates for loan shopping? "In trying to compare mortgage prices of different lenders, I understand that I have to look at the fees as well as the points that lenders charge, but ads in the newspaper only show rate, points and APR. If I remember correctly, you said that the APR includes all lender fees, but you also warned consumers not to use the APR. Why aren't lenders required to show all their fees in their ads rather than just the points?" Your question points up one of the critical failures of mandatory disclosure rules in the home loan market. Borrowers are overwhelmed with information they often don't understand, such as the Annual Percentage Rate (APR), and critically important information that they would understand is nowhere to be found. Aside from the interest rate, the single most important piece of information to a borrower is the total up-front credit charge -- the total that the borrower must pay the lender and mortgage broker for the loan. Yet lenders are not required to disclose it in either the Truth in Lending Statement (TIL) mandated by the Federal Reserve, nor the Good Faith Estimate of Settlement (GFE) required by HUD. Why's this? The Federal Reserve requires lenders to report the APR, which is a comprehensive measure of credit cost that takes account of the rate and most up-front credit charges. No doubt the Fed reasoned that since the borrower knew the APR, the figure for total credit charges that is used in calculating the APR was redundant. But it is not redundant, because many borrowers who would understand the figure for credit charges do not understand the APR, and are therefore reluctant to use it. APR assumptions There is good reason for borrowers to be leery of the APR, even if they do understand it. The APR assumes the borrower will be in the house for the entire term of the loan, which most are not. Borrowers who don't expect to have their mortgage for 10 years or more can easily be led astray by the APR. In an earlier column that is now on my Web site -- Does the APR Help? -- I give some concrete illustrations of this. If your time horizon is shorter than 10 years, it is more useful to know the credit charges used to calculate the APR than to know the APR itself. Using a calculator that I developed with Charles Freedenberg of DecisionAide Analytics, you can convert the one into the other. The APR fee calculator works backwards from the interest rate, points and APR on fixed-rate mortgages (FRMs) to derive the other up-front fees that were used by the lender to calculate the APR. How it works My local newspaper on September 20 quoted one lender as offering a 30-year FRM at 7.75 percent and 1 point, with an APR of 8.66 percent. Using a $100,000 loan amount. I entered these four items in the calculator, clicked on the "compute" button, and it told me that lender fees other than points amounted to $7,180. Note that APRs shown in the media assume a loan amount of $100,000 unless the loan is designated "jumbo," in which case the assumed loan amount is $250,000. The fees derived from the calculator using APRs shown in the media do not include all settlement costs. Mortgage insurance is not included in the APR until a borrower has been identified who requires it. Settlement costs that are not viewed as part of the cost of credit also are not included. These items include settlement/closing fees, abstract/ title search/title examination/title insurance costs, recording/filing fees, and city/county/state taxes. The APR calculator assumes that lenders have properly identified all the charges that should be included in the APR, and have calculated the APR correctly. There is a lot of anecdotal evidence to suggest that these assumptions are not always correct. Since mistakes will usually be in the direction of understating the APR, the user should place more credence in high charges -- such as the one cited above -- than in low ones.
